byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Vienna, Melissa Eddy from Berlin, and Palko Karasz from London.
byline.original: By ALISON SMALE, MELISSA EDDY and PALKO KARASZ

abstract: Grisly discovery of human remains in truck abandoned in Austria underscores concerns by European authorities of surge in human trafficking; say smugglers are exploiting desperate people fleeing strife-ridden places and willing to overpay for rides to prosperous European countries in overcrowded and unsafe transportation.
lead_paragraph: The discovery of 71 bodies in a truck in Austria, and the drowning of more than 150 people off the Libyan coast have led to new calls to focus on human trafficking.

headline.main: Grim Findings in Austria and at Sea Push Migrant Crisis Into Public View
headline.print_headline: Traffickers in Europe Sense Opportunity in a Crisis Driven by Despair

snippet: The discovery of 71 bodies in a truck in Austria, and the drowning of more than 150 people off the Libyan coast have led to new calls to focus on human trafficking.
